title: Aluminum Falls Slightly After Hitting 3-Year High, But Remains Up Over 23% Year-on-Year
summary: Aluminum prices eased to about $3,087–3,086 per tonne on January 7, 2026, down roughly 1.5% from the previous day after recently breaking above $3,100, the highest level in over three years.[1] Despite the pullback, prices are up around 6.8% over the past month and more than 23% compared with the same time last year, supported by tighter supply as China reiterates its cap on aluminum smelting capacity.[1]

title: NALCO Shares Skyrocket to Record High as Aluminum Prices Breach $3,000 Mark
summary: National Aluminum Company Ltd. (NALCO) shares jumped as much as 6% to a record high, driven by global aluminum prices crossing $3,000 per tonne, a level not seen in more than three years.[4] The rally is being fueled by supply constraints in China and Europe and strong demand from construction and renewable energy sectors, even as analysts caution that the stock’s current valuation may already price in much of the optimism.[4]

title: National Aluminium Share Price Today, January 8
summary: National Aluminium Co Ltd shares were trading down about 3.9% in early trade on January 8 after a strong run to fresh record highs in recent sessions, which had been underpinned by rising global aluminum prices and positive industry fundamentals.[5] The stock remains significantly higher over the past year, reflecting improved profitability and sentiment tied to the global aluminum price uptrend.[5]

title: Aluminium Price Spikes Driven by Global Supply Concerns in 2026
summary: London Metal Exchange aluminium futures recently climbed to about $3,008 per tonne in early 2026, breaching the $3,000 mark for the first time since mid‑2022.[6] The move is attributed to global supply concerns, including constrained capacity in key producing regions, which are tightening the market and supporting higher prices.[6]

title: North American Scrap Metal Prices Rise Across Copper, Aluminum, Stainless Steel & Brass
summary: A broad range of North American scrap metal prices, including multiple aluminum scrap categories, recorded gains as of January 2, 2026.[7] Aluminum grades such as 1100 Scrap, 3003 Scrap, 356 Aluminum Wheels, and several extrusion and sheet categories rose by around $0.01–0.02 per pound, indicating firm scrap demand alongside the primary aluminum price strength.[7]

title: Vedanta Aluminium scales Lanjigarh refinery and sets alumina production record
summary: Vedanta Aluminium has announced a new production record at its Lanjigarh alumina refinery, highlighting a significant scale-up in alumina output.[2] The achievement underpins Vedanta’s strategy to secure raw material supply for its aluminium smelting operations and strengthen its position in the global aluminium value chain.[2]

title: Commodity Radar: Bauxite helps to hold the capesize market
summary: China is keeping its primary aluminium production capped at 45 million tonnes per year, with output for the first 11 months of 2025 reported at 41.4 million tonnes, implying limited December production capacity to stay within the cap.[5] The article notes that this cap supports continued strong bauxite and alumina demand, and that growing aluminium smelting capacity in countries such as Indonesia could drive higher alumina exports from China and alter future bauxite trade flows.[5]

title: CES 2026: Reviewed announces its awards for tech's best products
summary: Features innovative aluminum alloy technology in consumer products, including a trademarked aluminum alloy that is significantly stronger than standard 6061 aluminum and outperforms TA2 titanium in key strength metrics. The material engineering provides exceptional resistance to dents, scratches, and long-term wear without adding bulk.

title: RPM Announces Acquisition of Kalzip
summary: RPM International has acquired Kalzip, a globally recognized leader in aluminum roofing and façade systems headquartered in Germany. The acquisition enhances the company's position in aluminum building envelope technologies and creates opportunities to expand these systems to North American customers.

title: Paragon Union, Japan's Asahi Seiren Form JV To Tap US$160 Billion Recycled Aluminum Market
summary: A joint venture between Paragon Union and Japan's Asahi Seiren has been formed to tap into the US$160 billion recycled aluminum market, reflecting growing industry focus on circular economy solutions and sustainable aluminum production.

title: Steel falls as China growth worries cap recent gains
summary: Benchmark Chinese steel prices slipped to about 3,146 CNY/ton, down around 0.4% from the previous day, even though they remain roughly 3% higher over the past month.[1] The market has been supported by expectations of fresh Chinese policy easing, but lingering concerns about construction demand and the broader economy are limiting further upside.[1]

title: HRC steel prices edge higher, extending strong year-on-year gains
summary: US hot-rolled coil (HRC) steel prices rose to about 937 USD/ton, up roughly 0.8% on the day and more than 33% higher than a year ago.[2] Analysts expect HRC to remain firm, with forecasts pointing toward prices near 960 USD/ton by quarter‑end and above 1,030 USD/ton in 12 months.[2]

title: North EU HRC futures continue to firm despite quiet spot market
summary: CME North European hot‑rolled coil futures moved higher, with second‑quarter strips trading around €676/ton as derivatives participants reported solid buying interest.[4] The strength in futures contrasts with a relatively subdued physical market but reflects expectations of tighter supply and steady demand into Q2.[4]

title: Stainless steel coil prices rise in China on stronger nickel and sentiment
summary: Prices for 304 2.0mm cold‑rolled stainless steel coil in China increased to about 13,400–13,500 yuan/ton in early January, up from roughly 12,800–12,900 yuan/ton in mid‑December 2025.[4] The gains track a sharp rally in nickel and improved macro sentiment, which are lifting stainless steel production costs and spot offers.[4]

title: Raw material prices rise sharply at the start of 2026, lifting stainless steel futures
summary: Key industrial metals such as copper, aluminium and nickel posted pronounced price increases in early January, with nickel up around 8% over two weeks amid talk of Indonesian output limits.[5] Stainless steel futures on the Shanghai Futures Exchange climbed nearly 2%, signaling potential upward pressure on finished stainless steel prices.[5]

title: Tata Steel India posts best-ever quarterly crude steel output in Q3FY26
summary: In its Q3 update, Tata Steel India reported its **best-ever quarterly crude steel production** at 6.34 million tonnes, up about 12% quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year, driven by higher output at its Jamshedpur and Kalinganagar plants.[1] The update also notes that Tata Steel Netherlands produced 1.68 million tonnes of liquid steel with deliveries of 1.40 million tonnes in Q3FY26.[1]

title: Tata Steel Q3FY26 update: Crude steel production rises 11.4% YoY; Europe lags
summary: Tata Steel India’s crude steel production increased **11.4% year-on-year to 6.34 million tonnes** in Q3FY26, with delivery volumes up 14% to 6.04 million tonnes, reflecting strong domestic demand.[2] In contrast, Tata Steel Netherlands saw a 4.5% decline in production to 1.68 million tonnes and an 8.5% fall in sales, while Tata Steel UK’s production was nil as both blast furnaces have ceased operations, leading to a 9% drop in delivery volumes to 0.52 million tonnes.[2]

title: Budget 2027: Assocham seeks incentives for hydrogen-based green steel production
summary: Industry body Assocham has urged the Indian government to offer incentives for **hydrogen-based direct reduced iron (DRI)** and concessional green finance to support the steel sector’s transition to low-carbon production in the FY27 Budget.[3] The group highlights that despite India’s 8–9% steel growth and position as the world’s second-largest producer, high input costs, dependence on imported coking coal, stagnant iron ore production, and pressure on raw material supply are constraining capacity and raising costs.[3]

title: Union Budget: Assocham seeks incentives for hydrogen steel, green finance
summary: Ahead of India’s Union Budget, Assocham has called for policy support including incentives for **hydrogen-based steelmaking**, concessional green finance, and stronger backing for recycling and R&D to help expand low-carbon steel capacity.[6] The chamber warns that elevated raw material costs, a weak rupee, and near-total reliance on imported coking coal are squeezing margins and could hinder future capacity additions without supportive measures.[6]

title: Gov't discusses response to EU's carbon tax policy with steel industry
summary: South Korea’s Ministry of Trade, Industry and Resources met with major domestic steelmakers to discuss responses to the EU’s **Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM)**, which began applying to carbon-intensive imports such as steel on January 1.[4] Steel producers said they have prepared compliance measures, including securing EU-recognized carbon verification, but requested continued government efforts to reduce uncertainties around the evolving policy, which could affect export competitiveness and future investment decisions.[4]

title: Europe's steel industry faces its 2026 reckoning with CBAM
summary: From January 2026, the EU’s **Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism** begins to materially impact Europe’s steelmakers, marking a turning point where climate policy starts to reshape steel sector balance sheets.[5] The article explains how CBAM aims to protect EU producers from carbon leakage by imposing a carbon cost on imported steel, which could influence capacity utilization, investment in low-carbon technologies, and the competitive landscape between domestic and foreign producers.[5]

title: International GalvaNext-2026 conference to begin in Jamshedpur on ‘Next Generation Galvanized and Color Coatings’
summary: An international GalvaNext‑2026 conference on next-generation galvanized and color coatings is being held in Jamshedpur, bringing together experts, researchers, and industry professionals from India and abroad to discuss hot‑dip coatings and advanced steel surface technologies.[5] The two‑day event emphasizes sustainability, emerging coating technologies, and future‑ready solutions for the galvanized and color‑coated steel industry, with over 70 technical papers and dedicated panels on technological innovation and long‑term strategic direction.[5]

title: Comex Copper Settles 3.35% Lower at $5.8090 — Data Talk
summary: Front-month Comex copper for January delivery fell 3.35% to $5.8090 per pound, snapping a three-session winning streak and marking its largest one-day percentage decline since late December 2025.[3] Despite the pullback, prices remain near historic levels, logging the third-highest close on record and standing more than 37% above year-ago levels.[3]

title: Copper surges past $13,000/t as bull run gains pace
summary: Three‑month copper on the LME closed at $13,230 per tonne, up 3.04% on the day and 5.8% since 2 January, as the metal’s bull run accelerates.[4] Prices are being driven by safe‑haven inflows amid geopolitical uncertainty and growing concerns over a 650,000–850,000 tonne copper concentrate supply shortfall in 2026, reflected in sharply lower benchmark TC/RCs for smelters.[4]

title: Copper – Price, Chart, Historical Data and News
summary: Copper prices slipped to about $5.93 per pound on 7 January, down 1.45% from the prior day after hitting fresh record highs near $6.06 earlier in the month.[1] Even with the latest pullback, copper remains up roughly 40% year‑on‑year, supported by tight supply expectations and strong investor interest.[1]

title: Bernstein issues new copper prices target for 2026
summary: Bernstein forecasts copper will average $11,500 per tonne in Q1 2026 before moderating to around $10,000 per tonne in the second half as market momentum fades.[2] The firm attributes today’s all‑time‑high prices above $13,000 per tonne to a mix of natural supply disruptions, labor issues, and speculative activity tied to the electrification theme, but warns that weaker EV demand and negative macro headlines could trigger sharp corrections.[2]

title: Copper prices near all-time high: Structural shift or speculative spike?
summary: MCX January 2026 copper futures climbed over 1.3% to around Rs 1,330 per kg, bringing domestic prices close to lifetime highs amid the global rally.[5] The article discusses whether the surge reflects a long‑term structural shift driven by energy transition demand or a shorter‑term speculative spike vulnerable to correction.[5]

title: The price of copper is expected to reach a historic high of $13,000 per tonne in 2026
summary: The article discusses expectations that copper prices could climb to about $13,000 per tonne in 2026, driven largely by structural supply constraints and accelerating demand from energy transition technologies.[4] It reviews current mine output, projected production growth, and the risk that new capacity additions will not be sufficient to close the anticipated supply gap in refined copper.[4]

title: Rewiring Sustainable, Clean Energy Future With Copper
summary: This article explains how copper’s high electrical and thermal conductivity, combined with its 100% recyclability, make it a critical enabler of the clean energy transition and circular economy. It highlights forecasts that copper demand for clean energy could nearly double by 2050, emphasizes that almost one‑third of global copper demand is already met through recycling, and describes mining-sector innovations to cut water and energy use while improving environmental performance.[1]

title: A Canary in an Urban Mine: Environmental and Economic Impacts of Urban Mining
source: Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS)
summary: CSIS analyzes how ‘urban mining’—recovering metals such as copper and gold from e‑waste—can be as cost‑efficient as traditional mining in China while offering a smaller environmental footprint.[4] The piece discusses how scaling recycling and urban mining could ease supply constraints for critical materials used in clean energy and high‑tech applications, reduce dependence on primary mining, and support more sustainable industrial systems.[4]

title: The Trends Shaping the Data Center in 2026 and Beyond
summary: Siemon outlines how evolving copper cabling technologies are supporting higher‑speed data center interconnects while helping operators meet tightening sustainability requirements.[5] The article details advances such as active copper cable assemblies and new mesh constructions that improve energy efficiency, thermal management, and material use, positioning copper as a key element of more sustainable AI and cloud data centers.[5]

title: SMM Nickel Midday Review: Nickel Prices Retreat from Highs on January 8 as Market Sentiment Shifts from Frenzy to Caution
summary: Nickel prices on the SHFE pulled back after a sharp rally, with the most-traded 2602 contract closing down about 2.3% around 142,020 yuan/mt, as sentiment turned from aggressive buying to more cautious profit‑taking.[1] Spot #1 refined nickel averaged 149,050 yuan/mt, down 1,100 yuan/mt day‑on‑day, while a sharp one‑day increase of 20,000 mt in LME inventories to 270,000 mt raised concerns about oversupply and near‑term volatility.[1]

title: Copper, nickel retreat from highs as rally loses steam
summary: Nickel prices on the LME fell about 2.3% to roughly $18,085 per tonne after earlier touching around $18,800, as the recent rally lost momentum amid profit‑taking.[6] Traders cited overextended positioning and questions about the sustainability of recent gains despite earlier strength driven by supply concerns and macro optimism.[6]

title: Nickel prices remain high despite copper nearing record levels
summary: Nickel prices hit a 19‑month high after the Indonesian government cut mining quotas for 2026, sending Shanghai nickel up about 7.3% to roughly 146,770 yuan/ton and briefly to its highest level since June 2024.[3] LME nickel also reached around $18,785 per tonne before easing, with analysts warning that weak fundamentals could make the market vulnerable to short‑term profit‑taking.[3]

title: Asian Nickel Prices Continue to Rise Sharply
summary: Asian nickel prices jumped by up to about 8% in the latest session, extending gains of more than 25% on the SHFE since early December 2025, driven by Indonesia’s plan to restrict nickel ore mining.[4] The sharp rise is feeding through into higher stainless steel spot prices in Asia and raising cost concerns for downstream industries.[4]

title: Nickel Prices Soar Over 10%, But Analysts Warn Rally Is Unsustainable
summary: Nickel prices have surged by more than 10% recently on supply fears and Indonesian policy moves, but several banks argue the rally overshoots long‑term fundamentals.[5] ING and the World Bank both project average nickel prices around $15,250–$15,500 per tonne in 2026, implying downside risk from current elevated spot levels.[5]

title: Nickel prices hit 15‑month high on robust sentiment
summary: Nickel climbed to a 15‑month high as bullish sentiment around Indonesian output restrictions and strong stainless steel demand outweighed concerns about ample supply.[8] Argus notes that despite the current spike, the average nickel price in 2025 was $15,349/t, down from $17,049/t in 2024, underscoring how recent gains contrast with prior price softness.[8]

title: Nickel prices jump after top producer Indonesia signals 2026 output cut
summary: Nickel prices rose to their highest level since March after Indonesia, which now accounts for over 60% of global nickel supply, announced plans to cut production in 2026 to balance the market.[2] Spot nickel climbed to about $16,500 per tonne from $15,800, while the three‑month LME contract rallied 6.4% as investors anticipated tighter supply and improved pricing power.[2]

title: Pressure for Indonesian quota U-turn is a risk for nickel price rally
summary: Indonesia, which accounts for about 70% of global nickel production, has cut mining quotas, helping drive nickel prices to around 19‑month highs near $18,800/ton and more than 30% above recent levels.[3] Analysts warn that political and industry pressure for a reversal of these restrictions could unleash additional supply later in the year as new projects ramp up and quotas are potentially relaxed, tempering the rally.[3]

title: Nickel prices surge on Indonesian curbs, but policy U-turn risk looms
summary: Indonesia’s decision to cut nickel mining quotas has sharply boosted global nickel prices, underscoring the country’s dominant role in supply.[5] However, the report notes that pressure is building for a potential policy reversal, which could eventually increase mining permits and production capacity, easing the current tightness in the market.[3][5]

title: SMM Nickel Midday Review: Nickel prices retreat from highs on January 8 as market sentiment shifts from frenzy to caution
summary: Nickel prices on the SHFE pulled back on January 8 after a strong rally, with spot refined nickel in China quoted at 143,400–154,700 yuan/mt and average prices down 1,100 yuan/mt from the previous trading day.[1] The review highlights a sharp one‑day increase of 20,000 mt in LME nickel inventories to 270,000 mt and notes that traders are closely watching Indonesia’s nickel policy and future production capacity as key drivers of volatility.[1]

title: Nickel still capped by surplus
summary: ING analysts forecast that the **global nickel market will remain in surplus through 2026**, with supply growth—driven largely by Indonesia—continuing to outpace demand.[1] The article notes that environmental scrutiny of Indonesia’s HPAL (high-pressure acid leach) projects and evolving EV battery chemistries, including a shift toward lower‑nickel LFP batteries, are reshaping the technology and sustainability landscape for nickel used in clean energy applications.[1]

title: Indonesian Nickel Quota U-Turn Pressure Drives Price Rally
summary: Discovery Alert reports that expectations of a **policy reversal on Indonesia’s nickel output quotas** have triggered a price rally in nickel markets.[4] The piece highlights how changing quota and infrastructure investment policies in Indonesia, a dominant producer for EV and battery supply chains, could influence future project economics, technology deployment, and the sustainability profile of nickel-intensive industries.[4]

title: The first Energy Release contract in the Aosta Valley is underway: agreement signed between the CVA Group and Cogne Acciai Speciali
summary: CVA will construct four new photovoltaic plants in Sicily with a total capacity of over 20 MW, expected to produce 593,600 MWh annually and be fully operational by 2026. This marks the first Energy Release agreement in the Aosta Valley and supports Cogne Acciai Speciali's green energy transition and reduced environmental impact of production.
query: Cogne Acciai Speciali news aluminum steel italy

title: Cogne Acciai Speciali signs agreement to acquire 65% stake in Com.Steel Inox
summary: Cogne Acciai Speciali signed a contract to acquire a 65% stake in Com.Steel Inox SpA from Com.Steel SpA, expanding its portfolio in the stainless steel sector.
query: Cogne Acciai Speciali news aluminum steel italy

title: Hydrogen to decarbonize steel: first trial launched in Italy
summary: Tenaris, together with Snam and Tenova, has launched what it describes as the first trial in Italy using hydrogen at a steel plant to process steel products. The six‑month project at Tenaris’s Dalmine mill in Bergamo will use on‑site produced hydrogen to fuel a new burner in a reheating furnace for seamless pipe rolling, aiming to cut CO₂ emissions and develop safety and operating guidelines for wider industrial decarbonization.[1]

title: Cavi in rame, Antitrust avvia indagine su presunto cartello: Prysmian e Nexans in calo in Borsa
summary: L’Autorità Antitrust italiana (AGCM) ha avviato un’indagine su un presunto cartello tra alcuni dei principali produttori di cavi in rame a bassa tensione in Italia, tra cui Prysmian Cavi e Sistemi Italia, ipotizzando un coordinamento sui prezzi a partire dal 2005.[1] Sono state effettuate ispezioni presso le sedi delle società coinvolte e di alcuni distributori; in Borsa il titolo Prysmian ha registrato un calo, anche se vari analisti stimano un impatto economico limitato perché il mercato italiano dei cavi in rame a bassa tensione pesa per meno del 3% sui ricavi del gruppo.[1]

title: Prysmian shares rise as Italian cable maker seen as winner amid US copper tariffs
summary: Le azioni Prysmian sono salite fino al 4% sulla Borsa di Milano dopo l’annuncio di nuovi dazi statunitensi sull’import di rame, con il gruppo visto dagli analisti come uno dei principali beneficiari grazie alla sua integrazione verticale e fornitura domestica di rame negli USA.[2] Gli esperti ritengono che Prysmian, grande acquirente globale di rame con un’importante presenza nel mercato americano, possa trasferire i maggiori costi ai clienti e rafforzare i margini nel business dei cavi a bassa tensione negli Stati Uniti.[2]
